 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(2.00)$, and get \[ \delta = \left[ \frac{\sqrt{2.00} \left(- 28.00 \epsilon \left(1.00 - i\right) \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right) \sqrt{- 64.00 \epsilon^{2.00} \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{4.00}} - 32.00 \sqrt{2.00} \epsilon \left(-1.00 + i\right) \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{9.00}{8.00}} - 3.00 i \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}} + i \left(1.00 + i\right) \left(28.00 \epsilon \left(1.00 + i\right) \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right) \left(4.00 \sqrt{2.00} \epsilon \left(1.00 + i\right) \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt[4.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)}{2.00 \cdot \left(28.00 \epsilon \left(1.00 - i\right) \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right) \left(28.00 \epsilon \left(1.00 + i\right) \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)}, \  \frac{\sqrt{2.00} \cdot \left(28.00 \epsilon \left(1.00 - i\right) \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right) \sqrt{- 64.00 \epsilon^{2.00} \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{4.00}} - 32.00 \sqrt{2.00} \epsilon \left(-1.00 + i\right) \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{9.00}{8.00}} - 3.00 i \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}} + i \left(1.00 + i\right) \left(28.00 \epsilon \left(1.00 + i\right) \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right) \left(4.00 \sqrt{2.00} \epsilon \left(1.00 + i\right) \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt[4.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)}{2.00 \cdot \left(28.00 \epsilon \left(1.00 - i\right) \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right) \left(28.00 \epsilon \left(1.00 + i\right) \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)}\right] .\] 
 Note that here we find 2.00 solutions for $\delta$ for the root $\overline{x} =\frac{\sqrt{2.00} \cdot \left(1.00 + i\right) \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}$ because we're calculating corrections to $\mathcal{O}(2.00)$. We need to apply the definition $\delta < \overline{x}$ to select the smaller one. We do this using our knowledge of the regime of validity for this root—since this root is valid for large $\epsilon$ we select (rounded to two decimal places) \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx-0.00 + 1.85 \cdot 10.00^{-6.00} i.} \] 
\underline{Root 7.00: $- \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =- \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta - \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)^{8.00} - \left(\delta - \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)^{3.00} - 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{8.00} \epsilon - 8.00 \delta^{7.00} \epsilon \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 28.00 \delta^{6.00} \epsilon \sqrt[4.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - 56.00 \delta^{5.00} \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{8.00}} + 70.00 \delta^{4.00} \epsilon \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - 56.00 \delta^{3.00} \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}} - \delta^{3.00} + 28.00 \delta^{2.00} \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} + 3.00 \delta^{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - 8.00 \delta \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} - 3.00 \delta \sqrt[4.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{8.00}}=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(2.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta^{2.00} \cdot \left(28.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right) + \delta \left(- 8.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt[4.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right) + \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{8.00}}\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(2.00)$, and get \[ \delta = \left[ \frac{8.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} - \sqrt{64.00 \epsilon^{2.00} \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{4.00}} - 64.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{9.00}{8.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}} + 3.00 \sqrt[4.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00 \cdot \left(28.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)}, \  \frac{8.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} + \sqrt{64.00 \epsilon^{2.00} \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{4.00}} - 64.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{9.00}{8.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}} + 3.00 \sqrt[4.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00 \cdot \left(28.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)}\right] .\] 
 Note that here we find 2.00 solutions for $\delta$ for the root $\overline{x} =- \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}$ because we're calculating corrections to $\mathcal{O}(2.00)$. We need to apply the definition $\delta < \overline{x}$ to select the smaller one. We do this using our knowledge of the regime of validity for this root—since this root is valid for large $\epsilon$ we select (rounded to two decimal places) \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx0.0012525700739077.} \] 
\underline{Root 8.00: $\sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =\sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta + \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)^{8.00} - \left(\delta + \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)^{3.00} - 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{8.00} \epsilon + 8.00 \delta^{7.00} \epsilon \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 28.00 \delta^{6.00} \epsilon \sqrt[4.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 56.00 \delta^{5.00} \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{8.00}} + 70.00 \delta^{4.00} \epsilon \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 56.00 \delta^{3.00} \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}} - \delta^{3.00} + 28.00 \delta^{2.00} \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} - 3.00 \delta^{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 8.00 \delta \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} - 3.00 \delta \sqrt[4.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{8.00}}=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(2.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta^{2.00} \cdot \left(28.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right) + \delta \left(8.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt[4.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right) - \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{8.00}}\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(2.00)$, and get \[ \delta = \left[ \frac{- 8.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} - \sqrt{64.00 \epsilon^{2.00} \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{4.00}} + 64.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{9.00}{8.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}} + 3.00 \sqrt[4.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00 \cdot \left(28.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)}, \  \frac{- 8.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} + \sqrt{64.00 \epsilon^{2.00} \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{4.00}} + 64.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{9.00}{8.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}} + 3.00 \sqrt[4.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00 \cdot \left(28.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)}\right] .\] 
 Note that here we find 2.00 solutions for $\delta$ for the root $\overline{x} =\sqrt[8.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}$ because we're calculating corrections to $\mathcal{O}(2.00)$. We need to apply the definition $\delta < \overline{x}$ to select the smaller one. We do this using our knowledge of the regime of validity for this root—since this root is valid for large $\epsilon$ we select (rounded to two decimal places) \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx0.00124762532638727.} \] 


 We have thus found $\mathcal{O}(2.00)$ corrections for all 8.00 root approximations in both regimes.

question:
Consider the polynomial\[P(x) =\epsilon x^{8} - x^{6} + 1.\] 
Find approximate expressions for all roots of the polynomial in the limit of small positive $\epsilon$ and large positive $\epsilon$. Use a series expansion to calculate improved formulae for these roots to order 1 i.e. calculate $\mathcal{O}(1)$ corrections for each root.
solution:
We begin by equating the polynomial to zero to solve for the roots: $P(x) = 0.00$ This problem can be rewritten in the form $A+B+C=0.00$, where: $A=\epsilon x^{8.00};$ $B=- x^{6.00};$ $C=1.00$

We find approximate solutions to the roots by considering the three possible dominant balances. For each dominant balance, we find the roots of the resulting equation and evaluate whether each balance is self-consistent for small or large positive $\epsilon$. \vspace{1em}

We start with the balance $A+B=0.00$, assuming that $|C|$ is negligible when compared to $|A|$ and $|B|$. Solving this for $x$ in terms of $\epsilon$ then gives us 2.00 non-zero roots: 
\[\epsilon x^{8.00} - x^{6.00}=0.00 \]\[ \implies \boxed{ x=\left[ - \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}, \  \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right].}\]
To verify that these roots are consistent with the assumption that $|A|, |B| \gg |C|,$ we substitute these found roots back into the terms $A$, $B$, and $C$ and compare their magnitudes. Using this method, we find that it is true that these roots are valid for small $\epsilon$, while validity for large $\epsilon$ is false.

\underline{Therefore, these roots are valid in the limit of small positive $\epsilon$ only.}\vspace{1em}

Next we examine the balance $B+C=0.00$, assuming that $|A|$ is negligible when compared to $|B|$ and $|C|$. Solving this for $x$ in terms of $\epsilon$ gives us 6.00 non-zero roots: \[1.00 - x^{6.00}=0.00\]\[ \implies\boxed{ x=\left[ -1.00, \  1.00, \  - \frac{1.00}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}, \  - \frac{1.00}{2.00} + \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}, \  \frac{1.00}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}, \  \frac{1.00}{2.00} + \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}\right].}\]
To verify that these roots are consistent with the assumption that $|B|, |C| \gg |A|,$ we substitute these found roots back into $A$, $B$, and $C$ and compare their magnitudes. Using this method, we find that it is true that these roots are valid for small $\epsilon$, while validity for large $\epsilon$ is false.

\underline{Therefore, these roots are valid in the limit of small positive $\epsilon$ only.}\vspace{1em}

Finally, we examine the balance $A+C=0.00$, assuming that $|B|$ is negligible when compared to $|A|$ and $|C|$. Solving this for $x$ in terms of $\epsilon$ gives us 8.00 non-zero roots: \[\epsilon x^{8.00} + 1.00=0.00\]\[ \implies\boxed{ x=\left[ - \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}, \  \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}, \  - i \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}, \  i \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}, \  \frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(-1.00 - i\right)}{2.00}, \  \frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(-1.00 + i\right)}{2.00}, \  \frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(1.00 - i\right)}{2.00}, \  \frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(1.00 + i\right)}{2.00}\right].}\]
To verify that these roots are consistent with the assumption that $|A|, |C| \gg |B|,$ we substitute these found roots back into $A$, $B$, and $C$ and compare their magnitudes. Using this method, we find that it is false that these roots are valid for small $\epsilon$, while validity for large $\epsilon$ is true.

\underline{Therefore, these roots are valid in the limit of large positive $\epsilon$ only.}\vspace{1em}

By the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra, a polynomial of degree 8.00 has exactly 8.00 roots. We have found 8.00 roots that are valid in the limit of small positive $\epsilon$ and 8.00 roots valid in the limit of large positive $\epsilon$. Our method therefore provides a complete solution to the problem, finding the correct number of roots in each $\epsilon$ regime. 

The roots of $P(x)$ for large positive $\epsilon$ are\[ \boxed{ \left[ - \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}, \  \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}, \  - i \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}, \  i \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}, \  \frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(-1.00 - i\right)}{2.00}, \  \frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(-1.00 + i\right)}{2.00}, \  \frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(1.00 - i\right)}{2.00}, \  \frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(1.00 + i\right)}{2.00}\right]} \]and the roots of $P(x)$ for small positive $\epsilon$ are\[ \boxed{ \left[ - \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}, \  \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}, \  -1.00, \  1.00, \  - \frac{1.00}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}, \  - \frac{1.00}{2.00} + \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}, \  \frac{1.00}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}, \  \frac{1.00}{2.00} + \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}\right]} \]We now need to calculate correction terms for these roots to give us better approximations. We consider the ansatz that the root is given by $\overline{x} + \delta$, where the correction term $\delta$ is the sum of higher order terms of $\epsilon$ that we initially neglected in our approximation $\overline{x}$. By definition, $ \delta < \overline{x} .$ 
We plug this ansatz into the polynomial and perform a series expansion in $\delta$. We keep terms only up to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$. Then, we set the expression equal to 0.00 and solve for $\delta$. \vspace{1em} 

\underline{Regime 1.00: valid for small $\epsilon$} 

\underline{Root 1.00: $- \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =- \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta - \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)^{8.00} - \left(\delta - \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)^{6.00} + 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{8.00} \epsilon - 8.00 \delta^{7.00} \epsilon \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 27.00 \delta^{6.00} - 56.00 \delta^{5.00} \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{2.00}} + 6.00 \delta^{5.00} \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + \frac{55.00 \delta^{4.00}}{\epsilon} - 56.00 \delta^{3.00} \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{2.00}} + 20.00 \delta^{3.00} \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{2.00}} + \frac{13.00 \delta^{2.00}}{\epsilon^{2.00}} - 8.00 \delta \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{2.00}} + 6.00 \delta \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{2.00}} + 1.00=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta \left(- 8.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{2.00}} + 6.00 \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{2.00}}\right) + 1.00\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx\frac{1.00}{2.00 \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{2.00}}}.} \] 
\underline{Root 2.00: $\sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =\sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta + \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)^{8.00} - \left(\delta + \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)^{6.00} + 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{8.00} \epsilon + 8.00 \delta^{7.00} \epsilon \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 27.00 \delta^{6.00} + 56.00 \delta^{5.00} \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{2.00}} - 6.00 \delta^{5.00} \sqrt{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + \frac{55.00 \delta^{4.00}}{\epsilon} + 56.00 \delta^{3.00} \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{2.00}} - 20.00 \delta^{3.00} \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{2.00}} + \frac{13.00 \delta^{2.00}}{\epsilon^{2.00}} + 8.00 \delta \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{2.00}} - 6.00 \delta \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{2.00}} + 1.00=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta \left(8.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{2.00}} - 6.00 \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{2.00}}\right) + 1.00\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx- \frac{1.00}{2.00 \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{2.00}}}.} \] 
\underline{Regime 2.00: valid for small $\epsilon$} 

\underline{Root 1.00: $-1.00$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =-1.00+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta - 1.00\right)^{8.00} - \left(\delta - 1.00\right)^{6.00} + 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{8.00} \epsilon - 8.00 \delta^{7.00} \epsilon + 28.00 \delta^{6.00} \epsilon - \delta^{6.00} - 56.00 \delta^{5.00} \epsilon + 6.00 \delta^{5.00} + 70.00 \delta^{4.00} \epsilon - 15.00 \delta^{4.00} - 56.00 \delta^{3.00} \epsilon + 20.00 \delta^{3.00} + 28.00 \delta^{2.00} \epsilon - 15.00 \delta^{2.00} - 8.00 \delta \epsilon + 6.00 \delta + \epsilon=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta \left(6.00 - 8.00 \epsilon\right) + \epsilon\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx\frac{\epsilon}{2.00 \cdot \left(4.00 \epsilon - 3.00\right)}.} \] 
\underline{Root 2.00: $1.00$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =1.00+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta + 1.00\right)^{8.00} - \left(\delta + 1.00\right)^{6.00} + 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{8.00} \epsilon + 8.00 \delta^{7.00} \epsilon + 28.00 \delta^{6.00} \epsilon - \delta^{6.00} + 56.00 \delta^{5.00} \epsilon - 6.00 \delta^{5.00} + 70.00 \delta^{4.00} \epsilon - 15.00 \delta^{4.00} + 56.00 \delta^{3.00} \epsilon - 20.00 \delta^{3.00} + 28.00 \delta^{2.00} \epsilon - 15.00 \delta^{2.00} + 8.00 \delta \epsilon - 6.00 \delta + \epsilon=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta \left(8.00 \epsilon - 6.00\right) + \epsilon\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx- \frac{\epsilon}{8.00 \epsilon - 6.00}.} \] 
\underline{Root 3.00: $- \frac{1.00}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =- \frac{1.00}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta - \frac{1.00}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}\right)^{8.00} - \left(\delta - \frac{1.00}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}\right)^{6.00} + 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get

\[\epsilon \left(\delta + \frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(-1.00 + i\right)}{2.00}\right)^{8.00} - \left(\delta + \frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(-1.00 + i\right)}{2.00}\right)^{6.00} + 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{8.00} \epsilon - 4.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{7.00} \epsilon \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 4.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta^{7.00} \epsilon \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - 28.00 i \delta^{6.00} \epsilon \sqrt[4.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - \delta^{6.00} + 28.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{5.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{8.00}} + 28.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta^{5.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{8.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{5.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta^{5.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - 70.00 \delta^{4.00} \epsilon \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 15.00 i \delta^{4.00} \sqrt[4.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 28.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{3.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}} - 28.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta^{3.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}} - 10.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{3.00} \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{8.00}} - 10.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta^{3.00} \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{8.00}} + 28.00 i \delta^{2.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} + 15.00 \delta^{2.00} \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - 4.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} - 4.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}} - i \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}}=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta \left(- 4.00 \sqrt{2.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} - 4.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}}\right) - i \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}}\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx- \frac{\sqrt{2.00} i \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{8.00 \epsilon \sqrt[4.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(1.00 + i\right) + 6.00 - 6.00 i}.} \] 
\underline{Root 7.00: $\frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(1.00 - i\right)}{2.00}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =\frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(1.00 - i\right)}{2.00}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta + \frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(1.00 - i\right)}{2.00}\right)^{8.00} - \left(\delta + \frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(1.00 - i\right)}{2.00}\right)^{6.00} + 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{8.00} \epsilon + 4.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{7.00} \epsilon \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - 4.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta^{7.00} \epsilon \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - 28.00 i \delta^{6.00} \epsilon \sqrt[4.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - \delta^{6.00} - 28.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{5.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{8.00}} - 28.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta^{5.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{8.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{5.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta^{5.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - 70.00 \delta^{4.00} \epsilon \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 15.00 i \delta^{4.00} \sqrt[4.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - 28.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{3.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}} + 28.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta^{3.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}} + 10.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{3.00} \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{8.00}} + 10.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta^{3.00} \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{8.00}} + 28.00 i \delta^{2.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} + 15.00 \delta^{2.00} \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 4.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} + 4.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}} - i \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}}=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta \left(4.00 \sqrt{2.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} + 4.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}}\right) - i \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}}\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx\frac{\sqrt{2.00} i \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00 \cdot \left(4.00 \epsilon \sqrt[4.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(1.00 + i\right) + 3.00 - 3.00 i\right)}.} \] 
\underline{Root 8.00: $\frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(1.00 + i\right)}{2.00}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =\frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(1.00 + i\right)}{2.00}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta + \frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(1.00 + i\right)}{2.00}\right)^{8.00} - \left(\delta + \frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(1.00 + i\right)}{2.00}\right)^{6.00} + 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{8.00} \epsilon + 4.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{7.00} \epsilon \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 4.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta^{7.00} \epsilon \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 28.00 i \delta^{6.00} \epsilon \sqrt[4.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - \delta^{6.00} - 28.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{5.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{8.00}} + 28.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta^{5.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{8.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{5.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta^{5.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - 70.00 \delta^{4.00} \epsilon \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - 15.00 i \delta^{4.00} \sqrt[4.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - 28.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{3.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}} - 28.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta^{3.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}} + 10.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{3.00} \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{8.00}} - 10.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta^{3.00} \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{8.00}} - 28.00 i \delta^{2.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}} + 15.00 \delta^{2.00} \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 4.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} - 4.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \delta \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}} + i \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}}=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta \left(4.00 \sqrt{2.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} - 4.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{7.00}{8.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}} + 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{8.00}}\right) + i \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{4.00}}\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx\frac{\sqrt{2.00} \sqrt[8.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00 \cdot \left(4.00 \epsilon \sqrt[4.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(1.00 + i\right) - 3.00 + 3.00 i\right)}.} \] 


 We have thus found $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ corrections for all 8.00 root approximations in both regimes.

question:
Consider the polynomial\[P(x) =\epsilon x^{6} + x^{5} - 1.\] 
Find approximate expressions for all roots of the polynomial in the limit of small positive $\epsilon$ and large positive $\epsilon$. Use a series expansion to calculate improved formulae for these roots to order 1 i.e. calculate $\mathcal{O}(1)$ corrections for each root.
solution:
We begin by equating the polynomial to zero to solve for the roots: $P(x) = 0.00$ This problem can be rewritten in the form $A+B+C=0.00$, where: $A=\epsilon x^{6.00};$ $B=x^{5.00};$ $C=-1.00$

We find approximate solutions to the roots by considering the three possible dominant balances. For each dominant balance, we find the roots of the resulting equation and evaluate whether each balance is self-consistent for small or large positive $\epsilon$. \vspace{1em}

We start with the balance $A+B=0.00$, assuming that $|C|$ is negligible when compared to $|A|$ and $|B|$. Solving this for $x$ in terms of $\epsilon$ then gives us 1.00 non-zero root: 
\[\epsilon x^{6.00} + x^{5.00}=0.00 \]\[ \implies \boxed{ x=\left[ - \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right].}\]
To verify that these roots are consistent with the assumption that $|A|, |B| \gg |C|,$ we substitute these found roots back into the terms $A$, $B$, and $C$ and compare their magnitudes. Using this method, we find that it is true that these roots are valid for small $\epsilon$, while validity for large $\epsilon$ is false.

\underline{Therefore, these roots are valid in the limit of small positive $\epsilon$ only.}\vspace{1em}

Next we examine the balance $B+C=0.00$, assuming that $|A|$ is negligible when compared to $|B|$ and $|C|$. Solving this for $x$ in terms of $\epsilon$ gives us 5.00 non-zero roots: \[x^{5.00} - 1.00=0.00\]\[ \implies\boxed{ x=\left[ 1.00, \  - \frac{1.00}{4.00} + \frac{\sqrt{5.00}}{4.00} - \frac{i \sqrt{2.00 \sqrt{5.00} + 10.00}}{4.00}, \  - \frac{1.00}{4.00} + \frac{\sqrt{5.00}}{4.00} + \frac{\sqrt{-10.00 - 2.00 \sqrt{5.00}}}{4.00}, \  - \frac{\sqrt{5.00}}{4.00} - \frac{1.00}{4.00} - \frac{i \sqrt{10.00 - 2.00 \sqrt{5.00}}}{4.00}, \  - \frac{\sqrt{5.00}}{4.00} - \frac{1.00}{4.00} + \frac{i \sqrt{10.00 - 2.00 \sqrt{5.00}}}{4.00}\right].}\]
To verify that these roots are consistent with the assumption that $|B|, |C| \gg |A|,$ we substitute these found roots back into $A$, $B$, and $C$ and compare their magnitudes. Using this method, we find that it is true that these roots are valid for small $\epsilon$, while validity for large $\epsilon$ is false.

\underline{Therefore, these roots are valid in the limit of small positive $\epsilon$ only.}\vspace{1em}

Finally, we examine the balance $A+C=0.00$, assuming that $|B|$ is negligible when compared to $|A|$ and $|C|$. Solving this for $x$ in terms of $\epsilon$ gives us 6.00 non-zero roots: \[\epsilon x^{6.00} - 1.00=0.00\]\[ \implies\boxed{ x=\left[ \frac{\left(-1.00 - \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[6.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}, \  \frac{\left(-1.00 + \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[6.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}, \  \frac{\left(1.00 - \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[6.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}, \  \frac{\left(1.00 + \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[6.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}, \  - \sqrt[6.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}, \  \sqrt[6.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right].}\]
To verify that these roots are consistent with the assumption that $|A|, |C| \gg |B|,$ we substitute these found roots back into $A$, $B$, and $C$ and compare their magnitudes. Using this method, we find that it is false that these roots are valid for small $\epsilon$, while validity for large $\epsilon$ is true.

\underline{Therefore, these roots are valid in the limit of large positive $\epsilon$ only.}\vspace{1em}

By the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra, a polynomial of degree 6.00 has exactly 6.00 roots. We have found 6.00 roots that are valid in the limit of small positive $\epsilon$ and 6.00 roots valid in the limit of large positive $\epsilon$. Our method therefore provides a complete solution to the problem, finding the correct number of roots in each $\epsilon$ regime. 

The roots of $P(x)$ for large positive $\epsilon$ are\[ \boxed{ \left[ \frac{\left(-1.00 - \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[6.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}, \  \frac{\left(-1.00 + \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[6.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}, \  \frac{\left(1.00 - \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[6.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}, \  \frac{\left(1.00 + \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[6.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}, \  - \sqrt[6.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}, \  \sqrt[6.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right]} \]and the roots of $P(x)$ for small positive $\epsilon$ are\[ \boxed{ \left[ - \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}, \  1.00, \  - \frac{1.00}{4.00} + \frac{\sqrt{5.00}}{4.00} - \frac{i \sqrt{2.00 \sqrt{5.00} + 10.00}}{4.00}, \  - \frac{1.00}{4.00} + \frac{\sqrt{5.00}}{4.00} + \frac{\sqrt{-10.00 - 2.00 \sqrt{5.00}}}{4.00}, \  - \frac{\sqrt{5.00}}{4.00} - \frac{1.00}{4.00} - \frac{i \sqrt{10.00 - 2.00 \sqrt{5.00}}}{4.00}, \  - \frac{\sqrt{5.00}}{4.00} - \frac{1.00}{4.00} + \frac{i \sqrt{10.00 - 2.00 \sqrt{5.00}}}{4.00}\right]} \]We now need to calculate correction terms for these roots to give us better approximations. We consider the ansatz that the root is given by $\overline{x} + \delta$, where the correction term $\delta$ is the sum of higher order terms of $\epsilon$ that we initially neglected in our approximation $\overline{x}$. By definition, $ \delta < \overline{x} .$ 
We plug this ansatz into the polynomial and perform a series expansion in $\delta$. We keep terms only up to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$. Then, we set the expression equal to 0.00 and solve for $\delta$. \vspace{1em} 

\underline{Regime 1.00: valid for small $\epsilon$} 

\underline{Root 1.00: $- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta - \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{6.00} + \left(\delta - \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{5.00} - 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{6.00} \epsilon - 5.00 \delta^{5.00} + \frac{10.00 \delta^{4.00}}{\epsilon} - \frac{10.00 \delta^{3.00}}{\epsilon^{2.00}} + \frac{5.00 \delta^{2.00}}{\epsilon^{3.00}} - \frac{\delta}{\epsilon^{4.00}} - 1.00=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[- \frac{\delta}{\epsilon^{4.00}} - 1.00\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx- \epsilon^{4.00}.} \] 
\underline{Regime 2.00: valid for small $\epsilon$} 

\underline{Root 1.00: $1.00$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =1.00+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta + 1.00\right)^{6.00} + \left(\delta + 1.00\right)^{5.00} - 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{6.00} \epsilon + 6.00 \delta^{5.00} \epsilon + \delta^{5.00} + 15.00 \delta^{4.00} \epsilon + 5.00 \delta^{4.00} + 20.00 \delta^{3.00} \epsilon + 10.00 \delta^{3.00} + 15.00 \delta^{2.00} \epsilon + 10.00 \delta^{2.00} + 6.00 \delta \epsilon + 5.00 \delta + \epsilon=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta \left(6.00 \epsilon + 5.00\right) + \epsilon\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx- \frac{\epsilon}{6.00 \epsilon + 5.00}.} \] 
\underline{Root 2.00: $- \frac{1.00}{4.00} + \frac{\sqrt{5.00}}{4.00} - \frac{i \sqrt{2.00 \sqrt{5.00} + 10.00}}{4.00}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =- \frac{1.00}{4.00} + \frac{\sqrt{5.00}}{4.00} - \frac{i \sqrt{2.00 \sqrt{5.00} + 10.00}}{4.00}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta - \frac{1.00}{4.00} + \frac{\sqrt{5.00}}{4.00} - \frac{i \sqrt{2.00 \sqrt{5.00} + 10.00}}{4.00}\right)^{6.00} + \left(\delta - \frac{1.00}{4.00} + \frac{\sqrt{5.00}}{4.00} - \frac{i \sqrt{2.00 \sqrt{5.00} + 10.00}}{4.00}\right)^{5.00} - 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get

\[\delta \left(- 3.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{6.00}} - 3.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{6.00}} - \frac{5.00 \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}{2.00} + \frac{5.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}{2.00}\right) - \frac{\left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{6.00}}}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{6.00}}}{2.00}\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx\frac{\left(\sqrt{3.00} - i\right) \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{6.00}}}{- 6.00 \sqrt{3.00} \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{6.00}} + 6.00 i \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{6.00}} + 5.00 \sqrt{3.00} \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}} + 5.00 i \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}.} \]

 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms

question:
Consider the polynomial\[P(x) =\epsilon x^{5} + x^{3} + 1.\] 
Find approximate expressions for all roots of the polynomial in the limit of small positive $\epsilon$ and large positive $\epsilon$. Use a series expansion to calculate improved formulae for these roots to order 1 i.e. calculate $\mathcal{O}(1)$ corrections for each root.
solution:
We begin by equating the polynomial to zero to solve for the roots: $P(x) = 0.00$ This problem can be rewritten in the form $A+B+C=0.00$, where: $A=\epsilon x^{5.00};$ $B=x^{3.00};$ $C=1.00$

We find approximate solutions to the roots by considering the three possible dominant balances. For each dominant balance, we find the roots of the resulting equation and evaluate whether each balance is self-consistent for small or large positive $\epsilon$. \vspace{1em}

We start with the balance $A+B=0.00$, assuming that $|C|$ is negligible when compared to $|A|$ and $|B|$. Solving this for $x$ in terms of $\epsilon$ then gives us 2.00 non-zero roots: 
\[\epsilon x^{5.00} + x^{3.00}=0.00 \]\[ \implies \boxed{ x=\left[ - \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}, \  \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right].}\]
To verify that these roots are consistent with the assumption that $|A|, |B| \gg |C|,$ we substitute these found roots back into the terms $A$, $B$, and $C$ and compare their magnitudes. Using this method, we find that it is true that these roots are valid for small $\epsilon$, while validity for large $\epsilon$ is false.

\underline{Therefore, these roots are valid in the limit of small positive $\epsilon$ only.}\vspace{1em}

Next we examine the balance $B+C=0.00$, assuming that $|A|$ is negligible when compared to $|B|$ and $|C|$. Solving this for $x$ in terms of $\epsilon$ gives us 3.00 non-zero roots: \[x^{3.00} + 1.00=0.00\]\[ \implies\boxed{ x=\left[ -1.00, \  \frac{1.00}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}, \  \frac{1.00}{2.00} + \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}\right].}\]
To verify that these roots are consistent with the assumption that $|B|, |C| \gg |A|,$ we substitute these found roots back into $A$, $B$, and $C$ and compare their magnitudes. Using this method, we find that it is true that these roots are valid for small $\epsilon$, while validity for large $\epsilon$ is false.

\underline{Therefore, these roots are valid in the limit of small positive $\epsilon$ only.}\vspace{1em}

Finally, we examine the balance $A+C=0.00$, assuming that $|B|$ is negligible when compared to $|A|$ and $|C|$. Solving this for $x$ in terms of $\epsilon$ gives us 5.00 non-zero roots: \[\epsilon x^{5.00} + 1.00=0.00\]\[ \implies\boxed{ x=\left[ \sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}, \  \frac{\sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(-1.00 + \sqrt{5.00} - \sqrt{2.00} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}\right)}{4.00}, \  \frac{\sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(-1.00 + \sqrt{5.00} + \sqrt{2.00} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}\right)}{4.00}, \  \frac{\sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(- \sqrt{5.00} - 1.00 - \sqrt{2.00} \sqrt{-5.00 + \sqrt{5.00}}\right)}{4.00}, \  \frac{\sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(- \sqrt{5.00} - 1.00 + \sqrt{2.00} \sqrt{-5.00 + \sqrt{5.00}}\right)}{4.00}\right].}\]
To verify that these roots are consistent with the assumption that $|A|, |C| \gg |B|,$ we substitute these found roots back into $A$, $B$, and $C$ and compare their magnitudes. Using this method, we find that it is false that these roots are valid for small $\epsilon$, while validity for large $\epsilon$ is true.

\underline{Therefore, these roots are valid in the limit of large positive $\epsilon$ only.}\vspace{1em}

By the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra, a polynomial of degree 5.00 has exactly 5.00 roots. We have found 5.00 roots that are valid in the limit of small positive $\epsilon$ and 5.00 roots valid in the limit of large positive $\epsilon$. Our method therefore provides a complete solution to the problem, finding the correct number of roots in each $\epsilon$ regime. 

The roots of $P(x)$ for large positive $\epsilon$ are\[ \boxed{ \left[ \sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}, \  \frac{\sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(-1.00 + \sqrt{5.00} - \sqrt{2.00} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}\right)}{4.00}, \  \frac{\sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(-1.00 + \sqrt{5.00} + \sqrt{2.00} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}\right)}{4.00}, \  \frac{\sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(- \sqrt{5.00} - 1.00 - \sqrt{2.00} \sqrt{-5.00 + \sqrt{5.00}}\right)}{4.00}, \  \frac{\sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(- \sqrt{5.00} - 1.00 + \sqrt{2.00} \sqrt{-5.00 + \sqrt{5.00}}\right)}{4.00}\right]} \]and the roots of $P(x)$ for small positive $\epsilon$ are\[ \boxed{ \left[ - \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}, \  \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}, \  -1.00, \  \frac{1.00}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}, \  \frac{1.00}{2.00} + \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}\right]} \]We now need to calculate correction terms for these roots to give us better approximations. We consider the ansatz that the root is given by $\overline{x} + \delta$, where the correction term $\delta$ is the sum of higher order terms of $\epsilon$ that we initially neglected in our approximation $\overline{x}$. By definition, $ \delta < \overline{x} .$ 
We plug this ansatz into the polynomial and perform a series expansion in $\delta$. We keep terms only up to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$. Then, we set the expression equal to 0.00 and solve for $\delta$. \vspace{1em} 

\underline{Regime 1.00: valid for small $\epsilon$} 

\underline{Root 1.00: $- \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =- \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta - \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)^{5.00} + \left(\delta - \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)^{3.00} + 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{5.00} \epsilon - 5.00 \delta^{4.00} \epsilon \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - 9.00 \delta^{3.00} - 10.00 \delta^{2.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{2.00}} - 3.00 \delta^{2.00} \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + \frac{2.00 \delta}{\epsilon} - \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{2.00}} - \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{2.00}} + 1.00=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\frac{2.00 \delta}{\epsilon} - \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{2.00}} - \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{2.00}} + 1.00\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx\frac{\epsilon \left(\epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{2.00}} + \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{2.00}} - 1.00\right)}{2.00}.} \] 
\underline{Root 2.00: $\sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =\sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta + \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)^{5.00} + \left(\delta + \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)^{3.00} + 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{5.00} \epsilon + 5.00 \delta^{4.00} \epsilon \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - 9.00 \delta^{3.00} + 10.00 \delta^{2.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{2.00}} + 3.00 \delta^{2.00} \sqrt{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + \frac{2.00 \delta}{\epsilon} + \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{2.00}} + \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{2.00}} + 1.00=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\frac{2.00 \delta}{\epsilon} + \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{2.00}} + \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{2.00}} + 1.00\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx- \frac{\epsilon \left(\epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{5.00}{2.00}} + \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{2.00}} + 1.00\right)}{2.00}.} \] 
\underline{Regime 2.00: valid for small $\epsilon$} 

\underline{Root 1.00: $-1.00$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =-1.00+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta - 1.00\right)^{5.00} + \left(\delta - 1.00\right)^{3.00} + 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{5.00} \epsilon - 5.00 \delta^{4.00} \epsilon + 10.00 \delta^{3.00} \epsilon + \delta^{3.00} - 10.00 \delta^{2.00} \epsilon - 3.00 \delta^{2.00} + 5.00 \delta \epsilon + 3.00 \delta - \epsilon=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta \left(5.00 \epsilon + 3.00\right) - \epsilon\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx\frac{\epsilon}{5.00 \epsilon + 3.00}.} \] 
\underline{Root 2.00: $\frac{1.00}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =\frac{1.00}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta + \frac{1.00}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}\right)^{5.00} + \left(\delta + \frac{1.00}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}\right)^{3.00} + 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{5.00} \epsilon + \frac{5.00 \delta^{4.00} \epsilon}{2.00} - \frac{5.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \delta^{4.00} \epsilon}{2.00} - 5.00 \delta^{3.00} \epsilon - 5.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \delta^{3.00} \epsilon + \delta^{3.00} - 10.00 \delta^{2.00} \epsilon + \frac{3.00 \delta^{2.00}}{2.00} - \frac{3.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \delta^{2.00}}{2.00} - \frac{5.00 \delta \epsilon}{2.00} + \frac{5.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \delta \epsilon}{2.00} - \frac{3.00 \delta}{2.00} - \frac{3.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \delta}{2.00} + \frac{\epsilon}{2.00} + \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i \epsilon}{2.00}=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta \left(- \frac{5.00 \epsilon}{2.00} + \frac{5.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \epsilon}{2.00} - \frac{3.00}{2.00} - \frac{3.00 \sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}\right) + \frac{\epsilon}{2.00} + \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i \epsilon}{2.00}\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx\frac{\epsilon \left(- \sqrt{3.00} + i\right)}{5.00 \sqrt{3.00} \epsilon + 5.00 i \epsilon - 3.00 \sqrt{3.00} + 3.00 i}.} \] 
\underline{Root 3.00: $\frac{1.00}{2.00} + \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =\frac{1.00}{2.00} + \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta + \frac{1.00}{2.00} + \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}\right)^{5.00} + \left(\delta + \frac{1.00}{2.00} + \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}\right)^{3.00} + 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{5.00} \epsilon + \frac{5.00 \delta^{4.00} \epsilon}{2.00} + \frac{5.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \delta^{4.00} \epsilon}{2.00} - 5.00 \delta^{3.00} \epsilon + 5.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \delta^{3.00} \epsilon + \delta^{3.00} - 10.00 \delta^{2.00} \epsilon + \frac{3.00 \delta^{2.00}}{2.00} + \frac{3.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \delta^{2.00}}{2.00} - \frac{5.00 \delta \epsilon}{2.00} - \frac{5.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \delta \epsilon}{2.00} - \frac{3.00 \delta}{2.00} + \frac{3.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \delta}{2.00} + \frac{\epsilon}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i \epsilon}{2.00}=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta \left(- \frac{5.00 \epsilon}{2.00} - \frac{5.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \epsilon}{2.00} - \frac{3.00}{2.00} + \frac{3.00 \sqrt{3.00} i}{2.00}\right) + \frac{\epsilon}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i \epsilon}{2.00}\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx\frac{\epsilon \left(1.00 - \sqrt{3.00} i\right)}{5.00 \epsilon + 5.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \epsilon + 3.00 - 3.00 \sqrt{3.00} i}.} \] 
\underline{Regime 3.00: valid for large $\epsilon$} 

\underline{Root 1.00: $\sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =\sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta + \sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)^{5.00} + \left(\delta + \sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)^{3.00} + 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{5.00} \epsilon + 5.00 \delta^{4.00} \epsilon \sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 10.00 \delta^{3.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{5.00}} + \delta^{3.00} + 10.00 \delta^{2.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{5.00}} + 3.00 \delta^{2.00} \sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 5.00 \delta \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{4.00}{5.00}} + 3.00 \delta \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{5.00}} + \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{5.00}}=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta \left(5.00 \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{4.00}{5.00}} + 3.00 \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{5.00}}\right) + \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{5.00}}\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx- \frac{\sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{5.00 \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{5.00}} + 3.00}.} \] 
\underline{Root 2.00: $\frac{\sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(-1.00 + \sqrt{5.00} - \sqrt{2.00} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}\right)}{4.00}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =\frac{\sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(-1.00 + \sqrt{5.00} - \sqrt{2.00} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}\right)}{4.00}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta + \frac{\sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(-1.00 + \sqrt{5.00} - \sqrt{2.00} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}\right)}{4.00}\right)^{5.00} + \left(\delta + \frac{\sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(-1.00 + \sqrt{5.00} - \sqrt{2.00} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}\right)}{4.00}\right)^{3.00} + 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{5.00} \epsilon - \frac{5.00 \delta^{4.00} \epsilon \sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{4.00} + \frac{5.00 \sqrt{5.00} \delta^{4.00} \epsilon \sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{4.00} - \frac{5.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{4.00} \epsilon \sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}}{4.00} - \frac{5.00 \sqrt{5.00} \delta^{3.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{5.00}}}{2.00} - \frac{5.00 \delta^{3.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{5.00}}}{2.00} - \frac{5.00 \sqrt{10.00} \delta^{3.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{5.00}} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}}{4.00} + \frac{5.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{3.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{5.00}} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}}{4.00} + \delta^{3.00} - \frac{5.00 \sqrt{5.00} \delta^{2.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{5.00}}}{2.00} - \frac{5.00 \delta^{2.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{5.00}}}{2.00} - \frac{5.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{2.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{5.00}} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}}{4.00} + \frac{5.00 \sqrt{10.00} \delta^{2.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{5.00}} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}}{4.00} - \frac{3.00 \delta^{2.00} \sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{4.00} + \frac{3.00 \sqrt{5.00} \delta^{2.00} \sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{4.00} - \frac{3.00 \sqrt{2.00} \delta^{2.00} \sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}}{4.00} - \frac{3.00 \sqrt{5.00} \delta \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{5.00}}}{4.00} - \frac{3.00 \delta \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{5.00}}}{4.00} -  and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms

 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta \left(- \frac{5.00 \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{4.00}{5.00}}}{4.00} + \frac{5.00 \sqrt{5.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{4.00}{5.00}}}{4.00} - \frac{5.00 \sqrt{2.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{4.00}{5.00}} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}}{4.00} - \frac{3.00 \sqrt{5.00} \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{5.00}}}{4.00} - \frac{3.00 \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{5.00}}}{4.00} - \frac{3.00 \sqrt{2.00} \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{5.00}} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}}{8.00} + \frac{3.00 \sqrt{10.00} \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{5.00}} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}}{8.00}\right) - \frac{\sqrt{5.00} \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{5.00}}}{4.00} - \frac{\left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{5.00}}}{4.00} - \frac{\sqrt{10.00} \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{5.00}} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}}{8.00} + \frac{\sqrt{2.00} \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{3.00}{5.00}} \sqrt{-5.00 - \sqrt{5.00}}}{8.00}\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx\frac{\sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(- 2.00 \sqrt{5.00} - 2.00 - \sqrt{-50.00 - 10.00 \sqrt{5.00}} + \sqrt{-10.00 - 2.00 \sqrt{5.00}}\right)}{- 10.00 \sqrt{5.00} \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{5.00}} + 10.00 \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{5.00}} + 10.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \epsilon \left(- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{5.00}} \sqrt{\sqrt{5.00} + 5.00} + 6.00 + 6.00 \sqrt{5.00} - 3.00 \sqrt{10.00} i \sqrt{\sqrt{5.00} + 5.00} + 3.00 \sqrt{2.00} i \sqrt{\sqrt{5.00} + 5.00}}.} \]

\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =\frac{\sqrt[5.00]{- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} \left(- \sqrt{5.00} - 1.00 - \sqrt{2.00} \sqrt{-5.00 + \sqrt{5.00}}\right)}{4.00}+ \delta \]

question:
Consider the polynomial\[P(x) =\epsilon x^{3} + x^{2} - 1.\] 
Find approximate expressions for all roots of the polynomial in the limit of small positive $\epsilon$ and large positive $\epsilon$. Use a series expansion to calculate improved formulae for these roots to order 1 i.e. calculate $\mathcal{O}(1)$ corrections for each root.
solution:
We begin by equating the polynomial to zero to solve for the roots: $P(x) = 0.00$ This problem can be rewritten in the form $A+B+C=0.00$, where: $A=\epsilon x^{3.00};$ $B=x^{2.00};$ $C=-1.00$

We find approximate solutions to the roots by considering the three possible dominant balances. For each dominant balance, we find the roots of the resulting equation and evaluate whether each balance is self-consistent for small or large positive $\epsilon$. \vspace{1em}

We start with the balance $A+B=0.00$, assuming that $|C|$ is negligible when compared to $|A|$ and $|B|$. Solving this for $x$ in terms of $\epsilon$ then gives us 1.00 non-zero root: 
\[\epsilon x^{3.00} + x^{2.00}=0.00 \]\[ \implies \boxed{ x=\left[ - \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right].}\]
To verify that these roots are consistent with the assumption that $|A|, |B| \gg |C|,$ we substitute these found roots back into the terms $A$, $B$, and $C$ and compare their magnitudes. Using this method, we find that it is true that these roots are valid for small $\epsilon$, while validity for large $\epsilon$ is false.

\underline{Therefore, these roots are valid in the limit of small positive $\epsilon$ only.}\vspace{1em}

Next we examine the balance $B+C=0.00$, assuming that $|A|$ is negligible when compared to $|B|$ and $|C|$. Solving this for $x$ in terms of $\epsilon$ gives us 2.00 non-zero roots: \[x^{2.00} - 1.00=0.00\]\[ \implies\boxed{ x=\left[ -1.00, \  1.00\right].}\]
To verify that these roots are consistent with the assumption that $|B|, |C| \gg |A|,$ we substitute these found roots back into $A$, $B$, and $C$ and compare their magnitudes. Using this method, we find that it is true that these roots are valid for small $\epsilon$, while validity for large $\epsilon$ is false.

\underline{Therefore, these roots are valid in the limit of small positive $\epsilon$ only.}\vspace{1em}

Finally, we examine the balance $A+C=0.00$, assuming that $|B|$ is negligible when compared to $|A|$ and $|C|$. Solving this for $x$ in terms of $\epsilon$ gives us 3.00 non-zero roots: \[\epsilon x^{3.00} - 1.00=0.00\]\[ \implies\boxed{ x=\left[ \frac{\left(-1.00 - \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}, \  \frac{\left(-1.00 + \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}, \  \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right].}\]
To verify that these roots are consistent with the assumption that $|A|, |C| \gg |B|,$ we substitute these found roots back into $A$, $B$, and $C$ and compare their magnitudes. Using this method, we find that it is false that these roots are valid for small $\epsilon$, while validity for large $\epsilon$ is true.

\underline{Therefore, these roots are valid in the limit of large positive $\epsilon$ only.}\vspace{1em}

By the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra, a polynomial of degree 3.00 has exactly 3.00 roots. We have found 3.00 roots that are valid in the limit of small positive $\epsilon$ and 3.00 roots valid in the limit of large positive $\epsilon$. Our method therefore provides a complete solution to the problem, finding the correct number of roots in each $\epsilon$ regime. 

The roots of $P(x)$ for large positive $\epsilon$ are\[ \boxed{ \left[ \frac{\left(-1.00 - \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}, \  \frac{\left(-1.00 + \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}, \  \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right]} \]and the roots of $P(x)$ for small positive $\epsilon$ are\[ \boxed{ \left[ - \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}, \  -1.00, \  1.00\right]} \]We now need to calculate correction terms for these roots to give us better approximations. We consider the ansatz that the root is given by $\overline{x} + \delta$, where the correction term $\delta$ is the sum of higher order terms of $\epsilon$ that we initially neglected in our approximation $\overline{x}$. By definition, $ \delta < \overline{x} .$ 
We plug this ansatz into the polynomial and perform a series expansion in $\delta$. We keep terms only up to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$. Then, we set the expression equal to 0.00 and solve for $\delta$. \vspace{1em} 

\underline{Regime 1.00: valid for small $\epsilon$} 

\underline{Root 1.00: $- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =- \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta - \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{3.00} + \left(\delta - \frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{2.00} - 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{3.00} \epsilon - 2.00 \delta^{2.00} + \frac{\delta}{\epsilon} - 1.00=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\frac{\delta}{\epsilon} - 1.00\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx\epsilon.} \] 
\underline{Regime 2.00: valid for small $\epsilon$} 

\underline{Root 1.00: $-1.00$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =-1.00+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta - 1.00\right)^{3.00} + \left(\delta - 1.00\right)^{2.00} - 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{3.00} \epsilon - 3.00 \delta^{2.00} \epsilon + \delta^{2.00} + 3.00 \delta \epsilon - 2.00 \delta - \epsilon=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta \left(3.00 \epsilon - 2.00\right) - \epsilon\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx\frac{\epsilon}{3.00 \epsilon - 2.00}.} \] 
\underline{Root 2.00: $1.00$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =1.00+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta + 1.00\right)^{3.00} + \left(\delta + 1.00\right)^{2.00} - 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{3.00} \epsilon + 3.00 \delta^{2.00} \epsilon + \delta^{2.00} + 3.00 \delta \epsilon + 2.00 \delta + \epsilon=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta \left(3.00 \epsilon + 2.00\right) + \epsilon\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx- \frac{\epsilon}{3.00 \epsilon + 2.00}.} \] 
\underline{Regime 3.00: valid for large $\epsilon$} 

\underline{Root 1.00: $\frac{\left(-1.00 - \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =\frac{\left(-1.00 - \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta + \frac{\left(-1.00 - \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}\right)^{3.00} + \left(\delta + \frac{\left(-1.00 - \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}\right)^{2.00} - 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{3.00} \epsilon - \frac{3.00 \delta^{2.00} \epsilon \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00} - \frac{3.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \delta^{2.00} \epsilon \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00} + \delta^{2.00} - \frac{3.00 \delta \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}{2.00} + \frac{3.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \delta \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}{2.00} - \delta \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - \sqrt{3.00} i \delta \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - \frac{\left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}{2.00} + \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}{2.00}=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta \left(- \frac{3.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}{2.00} + \frac{3.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}{2.00} - \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - \sqrt{3.00} i \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right) - \frac{\left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}{2.00} + \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}{2.00}\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx\frac{\left(-1.00 + \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{3.00 \epsilon \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - 3.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \epsilon \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 2.00 + 2.00 \sqrt{3.00} i}.} \] 
\underline{Root 2.00: $\frac{\left(-1.00 + \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =\frac{\left(-1.00 + \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta + \frac{\left(-1.00 + \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}\right)^{3.00} + \left(\delta + \frac{\left(-1.00 + \sqrt{3.00} i\right) \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00}\right)^{2.00} - 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{3.00} \epsilon - \frac{3.00 \delta^{2.00} \epsilon \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00} + \frac{3.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \delta^{2.00} \epsilon \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{2.00} + \delta^{2.00} - \frac{3.00 \delta \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}{2.00} - \frac{3.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \delta \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}{2.00} - \delta \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + \sqrt{3.00} i \delta \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} - \frac{\left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}{2.00}=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta \left(- \frac{3.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}{2.00} - \frac{3.00 \sqrt{3.00} i \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}{2.00} - \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + \sqrt{3.00} i \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right) - \frac{\left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}{2.00} - \frac{\sqrt{3.00} i \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}}{2.00}\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx\frac{\left(\sqrt{3.00} - i\right) \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{- 3.00 \sqrt{3.00} \epsilon \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 3.00 i \epsilon \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 2.00 \sqrt{3.00} + 2.00 i}.} \] 
\underline{Root 3.00: $\sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}$} 
\[ \overline{{x}} + \delta =\sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}+ \delta \] 
Substitute this into $P(x)$ for $x$ and equate to $0.00$: 
\[\epsilon \left(\delta + \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)^{3.00} + \left(\delta + \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right)^{2.00} - 1.00=0.00 \]
 We then expand this expression to get 
\[\delta^{3.00} \epsilon + 3.00 \delta^{2.00} \epsilon \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + \delta^{2.00} + 3.00 \delta \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}} + 2.00 \delta \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}=0.00 \] 
 and represent it as a series of $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ in $\delta$, discarding higher order $\delta$ terms 
\[\delta \left(3.00 \epsilon \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}} + 2.00 \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}\right) + \left(\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}\right)^{\frac{2.00}{3.00}}\approx 0.00 .\] 
 We can then solve the expression for the correction $\delta$ to $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$, and get \[ \boxed{ \delta \approx- \frac{\sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}}}{3.00 \epsilon \sqrt[3.00]{\frac{1.00}{\epsilon}} + 2.00}.} \] 


 We have thus found $\mathcal{O}(1.00)$ corrections for all 3.00 root approximations in both regimes.
